description: Landsat satellite image dataset consisting of multi-spectral values of pixels in 3x3 neighborhoods. The database contains spectral data from four digital images of the same scene in different spectral bands (two visible, two near-infrared). The task is to predict the soil type classification of the central pixel based on multi-spectral values.
creator: Ashwin Srinivasan, Department of Statistics and Data Modeling, University of Strathclyde

feature_descriptions.attr1-attr9: Pixel values in 3x3 neighborhood for spectral band 1 (visible green)
feature_descriptions.attr10-attr18: Pixel values in 3x3 neighborhood for spectral band 2 (visible red)
feature_descriptions.attr19-attr27: Pixel values in 3x3 neighborhood for spectral band 3 (near infrared)
feature_descriptions.attr28-attr36: Pixel values in 3x3 neighborhood for spectral band 4 (near infrared)

use_case: Land cover classification from satellite imagery. Applications include agricultural monitoring, environmental assessment, urban planning, and natural resource management. Useful for automated analysis of large-scale geographical areas.
data_generation: Landsat Multi-Spectral Scanner (MSS) imagery with spatial resolution of 80m x 80m per pixel. Sub-area of 82x100 pixels extracted from larger 2340x3380 pixel scene. Four spectral bands captured simultaneously.
ethical_considerations: Satellite imagery classification should consider privacy implications when applied to inhabited areas. Environmental monitoring applications should be used responsibly to support sustainable land use practices.

original_source.creator: Ashwin Srinivasan, Department of Statistics and Data Modeling, University of Strathclyde
original_source.publication: Ashwin Srinivasan: The Statlog Landsat Satellite Dataset

dataset_history: Dataset history not available for satimage
inference_notes: Use Case: Land cover classification from satellite imagery. Applications include agricultural monitoring, environmental assessment, urban planning, and natural resource management. Useful for automated analysis of large-scale geographical areas.
